MARCH 30, 51AA, 8PM. IRKUTSKIY AKADEMICHESKIY DRAMATICHESKIY TEATR IMENI N.P. OKHLOPKOVA. 34 F / 1 C. LIGHT SNOW.
Bundled up for warmer weather, the first thing you see when you step off the plane is the dazzling lights of Irkutsk, Russia. The plane already set high standards for your party; you'd be invited here as officials and guests, after all, experts in your field, which is impressive considering your year (or less!) of fieldwork for the company. The hotel is no less glamorous; it's a humble little thing, but still fancy enough to have a lot of space to move around for your week-long trip, even with two beds to a room (and with one of you, two bodies to one bed.) There's a letter on your bed, but the same contents for all of your You unpack and freshen up, reading over the same letter that was sent to all of you. It lists cordial greetings, expectations of job, length of job, and what you will be doing ‚Äî helping an international collaborative investigation of a recently discovered anomaly near their base. There's the mention of payment sent to your agency that promises to be generous. A warning of general physical and mental discomfort that may come with research. The usual. It also lists, in a tight handwritten scrawl, as if hastily amended to the letter, that you will meet at the Academic Theatre in the middle of Irkutsk ‚Äî and, the note reads, the play is on –©–µ–ª–∫—É–Ω—á–∏–∫. The Nutcracker.
11:19
It's a nice play, all things considered, a generous demonstration of local culture. You get your own box, but your generous benefactor is nowhere to be seen. The strings tremble and sigh upon the stage, and the dancing is graceful, mesmerizing; apparently they use anomalous media here, and it shows with how magical the ballet is, how you feel your souls tugged in another direction. It ends too quickly, and some of you might find yourselves with your eyes watering by the end of it, or wishing for more. As the group of you stand in the busy hall of the theatre, you start to wonder exactly where this Johannes Andreyev is, before a pink-haired man bounds up to you, dressed in casual attire that sticks out like a sore thumb. "LQCC?" He extends a gloved hand, meeting your eyes behind his glasses, turning to each one of you. "I'm Katsuo. Katsuo Sato. Dr. Andreyev is expecting you."

MARCH 31, 51AA, 2PM. ZHIGALOVSKY DISTRICT, LEONID BASE, IRKUTSK 14 F / -10 C. MODERATE SNOW.
The drive up to the base is perfect, if only slightly boring. Katsuo comes to pick you up like usual after 11am, just after breakfast; he even stops by at a nice coffee place to get you some drinks for the long drive ahead, warning that the weather is predicted to dip at night ‚Äî "though we'll get back here before it gets too dark," he says. "The professor doesn't want you to be out here for that late." The window shows you the city streets, still laden with snow, turn into houses and then all too quickly into the wild forests of Russia. Katsuo turns on some local station this time, droning on and on about politics, the weather, a talkshow, some election; the brief snatches of english offer a view of a world largely unchanged by anomalies, with close to no mention about them in day-to-day media. Katsuo doesn't stop driving the whole two hours, and aggressively speeds up to pass the handful of cars you see on the road, all the while snowfall pelts the windshield and lands around you in gentle clumps. Before long, you close on to the receiving station, a flat structure that sprawls miles in length; there's a cable cart hooked up to higher altitudes that Katsuo herds you on, and your breath fogs the heated glass as you take it up to the base, a miles-long research facility that hugs the mountain close. It looks down to a steep curve of forest and natural scenery, and though much of it is reclaimed by nature, you can imagine what it must've looked like when the meteor hit. Johannes and Kostya are there when you arrive to NORTHEAST VISITOR'S ENTRANCE, bundled up for the weather. "Good afternoon," Andreyev greets you.
